Ok, I accept your point about "Accept:" headers.
But then I would think it applies equally well to
OPTIONS requests.  Why not just send an accept
header with an OPTIONS request?  What does the
options header buy you?

-Alex-


On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> >
> > I like your version of the format quite a lot.
> > The only thing I'd like to see in it that is
> > missing is some way of finding out what
> > content-types are available via
> > content-negotiation.
>
> I'm not sure that's necessary, though.  A client should submit to the server
> the list of content-types that it understands (i.e. "Accept" header) and the
> server should choose from that list or return an appropriate error response.
> What value would it be for a client to get back a list of content-types that
> it didn't understand?
>
> Further, I should point out that the format I suggest does allow a server to
> return something like:
>
> GET accept: text/html, text/*, */*
> GET accept-encoding: compress, gzip
>
> Basically, just about any request header could be specified.  The example in
> my original post were just a sampling for demonstration and not the complete
> list of possibilities.
>
> > Regarding the options header on GET, I like that
> > as a concept, but the practice makes me nervous.
> > I'd like to avoid a proliferation of file formats
> > for this sort of thing.
>
> I don't understand your concern here.  As it is OPTIONS is woefully
> underutilized.  It makes sense that in this emerging world of new metadata
> constructs, esp. wrt web services, the OPTIONS feature could fit the bill
> nicely (at least for some uses).  Regardless of the suggested header, anyone
> could return any response-entity of any content-type for OPTIONS right now.
> There is no way we can avoid that.  What the header does is allow a resource
> to indicate that metadata is available via OPTIONS in certain formats.  This
> is more an ability to actively inform the client of OPTIONS abilities than
> it is a method of proliferating multiple content-types when using OPTIONS.
>
